Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Galilei and Poincare Invariant Calculations of the three Nucleon System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the project supported by this award is to create new computer programs to calculate the interactions and properties of systems of three nucleons (atomic number A=3) using the most general form of interactions allowed by the physical laws of nature. These new computer programs will be made publicly available, thereby allowing other researchers to explore different parameters of the interaction or different interactions without the need to write the intricate computer programs needed to explore a three-nucleon system. A main motivation for this study is to understand the complex interactions between protons and neutrons in the nucleus; however the computational techniques used can also be applied to other areas of physics where three-body interactions are present, such as atomic physics (research with cold atoms) and particle physics (quark interactions inside the proton).

The method of predicting the behavior of three or more interacting bodies is a long-standing problem in theoretical physics. While the interactions of two particles are fairly easy to calculate, the so-called three-body problem is much more difficult to solve. A method attributed to Faddeev is now widely used, but the implementation of the Faddeev equations requires long and involved calculations that are best suited for powerful computers. The traditional approach to calculating the Faddeev equations uses a mathematical technique called partial-wave expansion. However, as the energy increases in the three-body system, this mathematical technique becomes inefficient. The current project utilizes a novel mathematical approach of taking spin traces, which allows the three-body problem to be solved at much higher energies, and generally increases the flexibility of implementing a wider class of inter-particle forces. Hence, this project will provide a better theoretical framework for the investigation of the three-body problem than is presently feasible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though Einstein's theory of special relativity was formulated over 100
years ago, there are still unsolved issues when considering systems
that contain more than two particles, since in such a system pairs can
be influenced by the presence and motion of other particles. The
simplest system for which the role of the force between a pair of
nucleons (neutron or protons) in the presence of another nucleon can
be quantitatively investigated is the three nucleon system. Since the
three-nucleon problem can be numerically solved with controlled
errors, it provides an ideal theoretical laboratory for investigating
the effects of special relativity in a few-nucleon environment.  Over
the years, computational advances have extended the range of energies
for which the three-nucleon problem can be (numerically) solved
exactly.  However, including the effects of special relativity in a
quantum mechanical description of the three-body problem is remains a
challenge.  Integrating new theoretical and computational capabilities
to understand relativistic effects in the three-nucleon system was one
of the goals of this project.  Our calculations of the bound state of
three nucleons (e.g. Helium-3) resulted in a detailed understanding of
the of the role of relativistic effects and the first explicit
comparison between non-relativistic and relativistic wave functions,
which describe the velocity distribution between a nucleon pair and
the spectator nucleon.  We identified four different types of
relativistic corrections and show that those must all be treated
consistently in order to get an accurate determination of the effects
of relativity.  Accurate relativistic wave functions for Helium-3 and
Tritium nuclei will be needed as input to compute the distribution of
charge and currents in these nuclei, which will be measured in the
MARATHON experiment, which is an approved experiment for the 12-GeV
upgrade Jefferson National Laboratory.  The work carried out within
this project also paves the way for extending the the three-nucleon
bound-state calculations to treat high-energy collisions of two and
three nucleon systems. Collisions of a proton with a Deuterium target
at moderately high energies (around 250 MeV) indicates that our
current understanding of the nuclear forces between two and
three-nucleons is insufficient and some new short-distance physics may
come into play.  For such considerations it is crucial to be able to
carry out calculations that treat relativistic effects consistently.

While three-body models are an important tool to investigate questions
relevant what governs the to the underlying physics of the system, the
numerical codes to carry out realistic and precise three-body
calculations require a significant development and testing
effort. Thus the group of researchers using such important tools is
relatively small. In order to make our codes useful to a wider
community, we use a standard representation of the force between the
constituent particles in terms of operators, so that the different
forces can be substituted, once the new force has been cast into the
standard form. Having the backbone of suite of codes available may
allow educating and training of young scientists in applying advanced
computational techniques in their research.
